items.title: row-wise apply (axis=1) passes entire DF into function
items.body:
This line:
````
all_banners_pd["ssh_label"] = all_banners_pd.apply(
    lambda x: label_banners_pandas(x, "filtered_ssh_banner", ssh_regexes), axis=1)
````
applies the function to each row correctly. However, when swifter is added:
````
all_banners_pd["ssh_label"] = all_banners_pd.swifter.apply(
    lambda x: label_banners_pandas(x, "filtered_ssh_banner", ssh_regexes), axis=1)
````
the entire DataFrame is passed into the function. It does not seem to be respecting axis=1.

items.title: Swifter + Pandas: script does not move on after using swifter + apply()
items.body:
I have a script that loads data from MySQL. After that a Pandas DataFrame is built. On it I do apply several `apply` methods.

When I run the script, without `swifter`, this is the ouput:

    Duration Job0_sql:  0.011724
    Duration Job0_df:   146.875376
    <class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
    Int64Index: 3316 entries, 0 to 3315
    Data columns (total 57 columns):
    id                       3316 non-null int64
    routerName               3316 non-null object
    routerLabel              3306 non-null object

Meaning that the SQL query lasted 0.011724 seconds. The whole process on the DataFrame, 146.9 seconds. Finally I do print `df.info()`. It also generates some plots (.jpegs) from the data itself.

After using `df.swifter.apply(.)` along the code, the output shows something different, and does not move on...

    Duration Job0_sql:  0.012964
    Pandas Apply: 100%|██████████████████████████| 48516/48516 [00:57<00:00, 845.45it/s]
    Pandas Apply: 100%|██████████████████████████| 3316/3316 [00:00<00:00, 4463.01it/s]

I mean, after the `swifter` I'm not getting neither the time `Job0_df` nor the processing of the plots: the script just stops there after the progress bars.

Why is it that the code stops there? As per the [documentation][1], we only need to append the `swifter` keyword bebore the `apply` method.

Has anyone experienced something like this?

  [1]: https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter

items.title: swifter apply called too many times leading to wrong results
items.body:
Dear all,

Assume I want to apply a function to every row of a dataframe and store the result. If my df has a shape of [2,4] I will expect 8 items, with swifter I get 20.

```python
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randint(0,100,size=(100, 4)), columns=list('ABCD'))
df_tmp = df.head(2)

print(df_tmp.shape)

datas = []
def row2mongo(row, columns):
    index = row.name
    for col, name in zip(row, columns):
        data = {}
#         data = {'date': pd.to_datetime(index), 'name': name, 'value': float(col)}
        datas.append(data)
    
df_tmp.swifter.apply(partial(row2mongo, columns=df_tmp.columns), axis=1)

print(len(datas)) # [20] should be 8 
```

While using the default pandas .apply function I get the correct result

```python
datas = []

df_tmp.apply(partial(row2mongo, columns=df_tmp.columns), axis=1)

print(len(datas)) # [8] correct 

```

How it is possible? 

Thank you in advance,

Francesco Saverio

items.title: `redirect_stderr` in 0.295 breaks python 2 compatibility
items.body:
Not sure if this is a known consequence (understandable since python 2.7 EOL is coming soon), but- 0.295 breaks python 2 since `redirect_stderr` doesn't exist in python 2's `contextlib`.

I think [contextlib2](https://contextlib2.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) could be used here- I can make a PR if I find the time, but thought I'd post it here in the interim

items.title: Some code-simplification suggests
items.body:
Hello. Thanks for the cool library. I'm working on the second edition of my High Performance Python book and I'm going to include a section on Swifter. I'll also be demoing this in a couple of upcoming conference talks.

I'm taking a look through your code and I'll raise some suggestions if that's ok? For those you agree with I'd happily raise a PR.

https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/master/swifter/swifter.py#L262
`samp` was a mystery until I realised it was shorthand for `sample`. I'd suggest using the 2 extra characters for readability and adding a comment explaining the intention of the sample (to save figuring out the code that follows).

https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/master/swifter/swifter.py#L268
`assert` in production code is dangerous as `python -O` switches off assert checks: https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/modules.html#compiled-python-files

I ran foul of this recently https://twitter.com/pwang/status/1157239710193991682 and I've since switched to using Bulwark and following the `if ... raise ...` approach as Peter suggests, I'm in the process of writing some advice docs given that I teach this in my public courses: https://github.com/ZaxR/bulwark/issues/46

Maybe something like the following works (assuming I've correctly understood the intent):

```
sample_result = sample.apply(...)
if not sample_result.equals(tmp_df):
    raise AssertionError("Attempt at applying the function to a sample has failed") 
else:
    return func(self._obj, *args, **kwds)
```

https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/master/swifter/swifter.py#L283
`n_repeats = 3` generally I'd suggest using the CONSTANTS convention i.e. `N_REPEATS = 3`.

https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/master/swifter/swifter.py#L272
Do we need the `:` after the exception? We could catch the exception with a `pass` and then I think  the following code would run just the same? If so, it'd be easier to parse as a 3rd person who is unfamiliar with the code.

https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/master/swifter/swifter.py#L300
I think these two returns can be compressed to something like:

```
if ...
  returned_func = self._obj.progress_apply
else:
  returned_func = self._obj.apply

return returned_func(
    func,
    axis=axis,
    broadcast=broadcast,
    raw=raw,
    reduce=reduce,
    result_type=result_type,
    args=args,
    **kwds
)
```

items.title: ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero` when using apply with small data frames
items.body:
Dear,

Since I updated my swifter version from version 0.285 to version 0.287 I'm having problems with the _apply_ function, particularly in small pandas dataframe. Here is an example of how I am using the function:

`mydf.swifter.progress_bar(False).apply(lambda x: some_func(x))`

Here is the specific part of the output error that points to a swifter error:

` /lib/python3.6/site-packages/swifter/swifter.py", line 167, in apply
    est_apply_duration = samp_proc_est / self._SAMP_SIZE * self._obj.shape[0]
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero`

Doing some diging on this Github repo I found that on [this](https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/commit/31901cc4c42fe92b8587b4baab13cf2154fb1745#diff-ad242a04628a718c8239819a28aefa41) commit some lines were changed and in particularly the _SAMP_SIZE class attribute was added. I have the felling that there is some error in class initialziation because when you call apply function with a data frame with less rows than 25000, _SAMP_SIZE are calculated as 0 value.

Any idea?

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Possible bug in allow_dask_on_strings
items.body:
https://github.com/jmcarpenter2/swifter/blob/3b693c1977c1d67951874e756043be1947c80fe7/swifter/swifter.py#L146

Shouldn't it be `if self._allow_dask_on_strings ` instead of `if not self._allow_dask_on_strings`?
(and the same in DataFrameAccessor)

Currently it looks like if we set `self._allow_dask_on_strings` to True and pass string series, `str_processing` will be False which is not we want probably.

Michael

def model_wrapper(parameters):
    if not isinstance(parameters, pd.Series):

    return model(**parameters)

items.title: pd.Series.swift.apply out differs from pd.Series.apply where arg is a Series of dictionaries
items.body:
My context: I have a column in my DF, a series of dictionaries, that I want to create another DF from.

The issue is that I expected pd.Series.swift.apply and pd.Series.apply to have the same output.

Let's define a series of dictionaries:

```
aDict = {"a": 1, "b": 2}
bDict = {"a": 3, "b": 4}
s = pd.Series([aDict, bDict])
```

Applying pd.Series.apply to this will create a DataFrame:
`s.apply(pd.Series)`

a | b
-- | --
1 | 2
3 | 4

Whereas applying pd.Series.swifter.apply to this will return the same series of dictionaries:
`s.swifter.apply(pd.Series)`

0    {'a': 1, 'b': 2}
1    {'a': 3, 'b': 4}

items.title: *args deserve more explanations...
items.body:
First of all, thanks for making such a great library. This literally SAVED my life. 
The idea of letting people take advantage of vectorizing and multi-threading on Pandas is just wonderful. 

However because this library is relatively new, I don't get much information from googling swifter.

This time I wanted to swiftapply values from 2 columns and I had no idea how to do this. 
I eventually figured out I should just repeat like below but it was hard (for me) to figure it out. 
```

def anyfunction(a,b,c):
    blablabla

df["New_Column"] = swiftapply(df["A"], anyfunction , b = df["B"], c = df["C"])

```

Moreover, it was even harder to get the clear picture of how these parameters look like when they are inside my function. 

First I tried to compare two values like

```
def anyfunction(a,b,c):
    if a > b:
        return foo

```
However, I later figured out this could not be done because they originally come in the form of pd.Series. I had no idea this would have been the case before a lot of debugs. 

Someone else can be confused too because while the above function doesn't work, the below works:

```
def anyfunction(a,b,c):
    return a + b

```

So the origin of confusion is that the arguments are always pd.Series in swiftapply but sometimes they behave like normal values and sometimes not. 
Sometimes they can be 'a', but other times they should be 'a[0]'. 

I think many people will be less confused if these things were somewhere in the document as examples. 


Anyway, again thanks for your great library. This is just beautiful.
